definitions.definition: an investigation of the opinions, behaviour, etc. of a particular group of people, which is usually done by asking them questions

examples.text: A **recent ****survey showed** 75 per cent of those questioned were in favour of the plan.
**According to the survey**, many young adults have experimented with drugs of some kind.
Another **national survey** conducted last year found the same result.
Roughly half of survey respondents express strong interest in additional education.
The **results of the survey** come as no surprise to us.
94% of people who took part in the survey said they agreed.
A customer satisfaction survey highlighted the need for clearer pricing.
The charity did a survey of people's attitudes to ageing.
A survey into conditions in schools revealed the need for much greater investment.
The researchers used a combination of survey methods.
They are carrying out a survey of small businesses in London.
This is the largest independent survey into health ever carried out in Britain.

definitions.definition: the act of examining and recording the measurements, features, etc. of an area of land in order to make a map or plan of it

examples.text: an aerial survey *(= made by taking photographs from a plane, , etc.)
A geological survey revealed the presence of oil beneath the ground.

definitions.definition: an examination of the condition of a house, etc., usually done for somebody who is thinking of buying it
a general study, view or description of something

examples.text: a comprehensive survey of modern music
a historical survey of children's clothing

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘examine and ascertain the condition of’): from Anglo-Norman French surveier, from medieval Latin supervidere, from super- ‘over’ + videre ‘to see’. The early sense of the noun (late 15th cent.) was ‘supervision’.
